entity.name: Nephthys - Lady of the House
entity.subtitle: Lady of the House - Goddess of Death, Funerary Rites, and Hidden Things
entity.description: Nephthys is the mysterious goddess of death, night, and mourning in ancient Egyptian mythology. As the "Lady of the House" and "Lady of Hidden Things," she presides over funerary rites, protects the dead on their journey through the underworld, and stands as the divine mourner alongside her sister Isis. Though wife of Set, she aided Isis in resurrecting Osiris and is mother to Anubis through a union with Osiris. Her presence represents the unseen aspects of existence‚Äîdarkness, secrets, and the transition between life and death.

attributes.Titles: Lady of the House (Nebet-Het), Lady of Hidden Things, Goddess of the Night, Mistress of the Temple, Friend of the Dead, Revealer of the Unseen, Divine Mourner
attributes.Domains: Death, funerary rites, mourning, night, darkness, hidden things, protection of the dead, transition, secrets, temples, service
attributes.Symbols: House/basket hieroglyph on her head, wings (spread over the dead), ankh, tyet knot, funerary bed, temple enclosure
attributes.SacredAnimals: Kite bird (bird of prey, form she took when mourning Osiris), jackal (through association with son Anubis), night birds
attributes.SacredPlants: Myrrh (funerary incense), frankincense, lotus (rebirth), acacia (associated with death rituals)
attributes.Colors: Indigo (deep night), purple (mourning), black (death and mystery), white (funerary linen), silver (moonlight)

mythology_stories.intro: Nephthys's mythology centers on her roles as divine mourner, protector of the dead, and guardian of hidden knowledge. Though married to Set, she allied with Isis and Osiris, representing the complexity of loyalty and the power of compassion over obligation.

key_myths.name: AidingIsisin ResurrectingOsiris
key_myths.description: Aiding Isis in Resurrecting Osiris: When Set murdered and dismembered Osiris, Nephthys betrayed her husband to help her sister Isis. Together, the two sisters searched throughout Egypt, gathering the scattered pieces of Osiris. They transformed into kite birds, circling over the reassembled body while chanting the "Lamentations of Isis and Nephthys," powerful magical incantations that helped restore Osiris to temporary life. This ritual became the prototype for all Egyptian funerary rites, with professional mourners reenacting the roles of Isis and Nephthys at every funeral. Nephthys represented the hidden, darker aspects of mourning and death‚Äîthe night to Isis's day, the shadow to her light.

key_myths.name: The Birth ofAnubis
key_myths.description: The Birth of Anubis: In one tradition, Nephthys was childless in her marriage to the sterile Set. Desiring a child and attracted to the vitality of Osiris, she disguised herself as Isis and seduced him. From this union was born Anubis, the jackal-headed god of mummification. Fearing Set's wrath, Nephthys abandoned the infant in the wilderness. Isis, discovering the child, raised him as her own with compassion rather than jealousy. Anubis grew to become the divine embalmer who would prepare his father Osiris for resurrection‚Äîa fitting role that connected mother and son through death rites. This myth explains Nephthys's association with hidden things (the secret affair) and her deep connection to funerary practices through her son.

key_myths.name: Guardian of the Coffin
key_myths.description: In funerary texts and art, Nephthys stands as one of the four protective goddesses guarding the corners of the coffin and the canopic shrine. She specifically protects the canopic jar containing the lungs (guarded by the god Hapy, one of the Four Sons of Horus). Her wings spread protectively over the deceased, shielding them from malevolent forces in the underworld. In the Book of the Dead, she speaks protective spells that guide the deceased through the dangerous passages of the Duat. Unlike Isis, who represents resurrection and return to life, Nephthys ensures peaceful passage into death and protection within the realm of the dead.

key_myths.name: The Invisible Companion
key_myths.description: Nephthys was called "Lady of Hidden Things" because she represented everything unseen‚Äîthe darkness of night when mysteries occur, the hidden processes of decay that must happen before rebirth, the secret knowledge possessed only by priestesses and embalmers. While Isis performed visible, active magic, Nephthys worked in shadows and silence. She was present at every death but rarely invoked directly, her power operating through subtle influence rather than dramatic intervention. Her name itself‚Äî"Lady of the House"‚Äîrefers to the temple enclosure or the "house" of death (tomb), the hidden dwelling place where the dead reside.

mythology_stories.sources: Pyramid Texts,Coffin Texts,Book of the Dead, "Lamentations ofIsisandNephthys" ritual texts, Temple inscriptions at Kom Ombo and Edfu, Plutarch's "De Iside et Osiride"

relationships.allies: Isis(primary ally and partner in mourning),Osiris(aided in his resurrection),Anubis(her son), the Four Sons ofHorus(especially Hapy whom she protects),Selket, Neith (fellow protective goddesses of the dead)

family.parents: Geb(earth god) andNut(sky goddess) - born on the fifth and final epagomenal day
family.consorts: Set(brother-husband), though she betrayed him to aidIsisand had a union withOsiris
